title: They're Toast!
question_text:
A company has two assembly lines for making toasters. One assembly line (line A) has been producing $2\%$ of its toasters as defective while the other assembly line (line B) has been producing $4\%$ defective. The company president is unhappy about this and wants to randomly sample $500$ toasters from each assembly line. What is the probability, to the nearest whole percent, of line B producing more than $3\%$ defective toasters than line A?
What is the probability, to the nearest whole percent, of line B producing more than $3\%$ defective toasters than line A?
solution:
Solution

To calculate this probability we need to first calculate the parameters for the sampling distribution of the difference of these two proportions. Those parameters are the mean and the standard deviation.

The mean is equal to pB−pA. Plugging in we get 0.04−0.02=0.02.

The standard deviation is given by this formula:

pB(1−pB)

Filling in our values where both values of n are equal to 500 and the two given proportions are 0.02 and 0.04 we get:

≈0.011

Choice 'A' is incorrect. This value represents the doubled proportion.

Choice 'B' is incorrect. This represents the z-score subtracted from 1
